pageContent: Background: In 2012, the United States Preventative Services Task Force issued new guidelines recommending that male U.S. residents, irrespective of race, no longer be screened for prostate cancer. In African American men, the incidence of prostate cancer is almost 60 % higher and the mortality rate is two to three times greater than in Caucasians. The purpose of this study is to reduce African American men's prostate cancer burden by demonstrating they need separate screening guidelines.

metaData.source:
Urinary, sexual, and bowel dysfunction and bother after radical prostatectomy
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18217536/
